description: From Middle English gre, from Old French gré, from Latin gradum (“step”). Compare degree. Doublet of grade.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) One of a flight of steps.
(obsolete) A stage in a process; a degree of rank or station.
examples: He is a shepherd great in gree.

entries.meaning: (now Scotland) Pre-eminence; victory or superiority in combat (hence also, the prize for winning a combat).

description: From (pre-reform) Scottish Gaelic gré, from Old Scottish Gaelic gray.

entries.meaning: (now Scotland) Pre-eminence; victory or superiority in combat (hence also, the prize for winning a combat).
examples: bycause Sir Palomydes beganne fyrste, and never he wente nor rode oute of the fylde to repose hym, but ever he was doynge on horsebak othir on foote, and lengest durynge, Kynge Arthure and all the kynges gaff Sir Palomydes the honoure and the gre as for that day.

description: From Middle English gre, from Old French gré (“pleasure, goodwill”), from Latin gratum, a noun use of the neuter of gratus (“pleasing”).

examples: Accept in gree, my lord, the words I spoke.

description: From Middle English green (“to agree”), from Old French greer, from gré (hence Etymology 3).

verbs.description: gree (third-person singular simple present grees, present participle greeing, simple past and past participle greed)
